instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light. <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 1.15v
threads.message:
Dead.  No LED and no fan. No obvious liquid.

SMC area looks good.

<CHIP>U5110</CHIP> looks good.

<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> area looks good.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is only 8.18v

<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is always 1.15v

If I jump <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> with tweezers the fan starts and green light comes on.

Measuring <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> I am only getting 80k instead of 100k.  But I am also measuring it on the board, so maybe that's wrong.  

Should <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> still measure 100k even in circuit? Anything else to check?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light. <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 1.15v
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> is good for sure.
Clean J6100, if looks ugly; can be removed.
Remove <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> and check if <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> goes high.
If not, remove <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR> and check again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light. <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 1.15v
threads.message:
J6100 looks good.

I removed <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>.  <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is still low, but for some reason green light comes on now.  No orange light with battery connected though and no fan.

I also removed <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR> but <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is still low, but it's higher than before.  It was around 1.15v but now around 1.6v.

EDIT: No green light anymore after unplugging for a while.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light. <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 1.15v
threads.message:
Change <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR>.
If still low, reflow SMC.
Last option, change SMC; you can reballing it first.

Put back <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>, if is not the culprit...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light. <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 1.15v
threads.message:
It was <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR>.

Replaced it and it measures 100k even while in circuit.  (y)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light. <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 1.15v
threads.message:
This thing worked for a few days then quit.  

I reflowed SMC and it worked for a few more days but now quit again.

Back to the same problem.  <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> now measures low and SMC reset is 0.7v.  I can still bridge <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> and make fan start.

I suspect it needs new SMC although there was never any water damage.  Thoughts?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light. <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 1.15v
threads.message:
I just pushed on the opposite side of the board from SMC and it made green light come on.  Still no fan.  

Must be ball under SMC right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light. <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 1.15v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light. <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 1.15v
threads.message:
This thing is still giving trouble.  

I did a reball on SMC and the job went very smoothly.  I tested it over the weekend by powering it up and down at least 10 times.

Now today it's back to no green light. 

Is it worth trying to source a new SMC or is there something else going on?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light. <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 1.15v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light. <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 1.15v
threads.message:
It looks like I have a new problem now.  <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is non existent and  <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is short to ground at 1 ohm.

I won't have access to my DC power supply or hot air until later today, but noticed that with Magsafe connected that <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> gets kind of hot, but not extremely. Hot enough to evaporate ISO alcohol though. Maybe he is the problem? 

I just hope the SMC hasn't failed because I don't have any more.  I would think my reball job was good since the machine behaved well for days after doing the job, but maybe not...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light. <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 1.15v
threads.message: Lift L7095 one side and check where the short remains.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light. <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 1.15v
threads.message:
Thanks for the reply.  The short is actually gone now and board is currently working again.

Yesterday I had confirmed with two different meters that it was short at around 1 ohm.

Then I attempted  to use DC power supply to heat up the short.  I limited it to around 1.5A touched the short.  

NOTHING happened.  Power supply didn't budge. No fan, no noise, no spark and no amperage.  It was like my power supply wasn't connected at all.

I was confused about what was happening so I checked for the short again.  Now it's gone.

Did the short burn out instantly when DC power was connected?  Like a small fleck of solder maybe?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light. <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 1.15v
threads.message:
This symptom points to  some cap with partial short.
The short can come back in the future, as that cap is corroded.
